summary: Background Enterovirus 71 (EV71) has been implicated in numerous epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease. it is associated with severe neurological complications and has caused significant mortalities in recent large-scale outbreaks. currently no effective vaccine or specific clinical therapy is available against EV71. EV71-infected children can develop neurological complications, such as aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, encephalitis, acute cerebellar ataxia, brainstem encephalitis, as well as fatal pulmonary edema or cardiopulmonary collapse. RNAi is a biological and specific post-transcriptional gene silencing mechanism that has been employed in the development of promising therapeutic agents. chemically modified siRNAs can be optimized by incorporation of chemically modified RNA analogues against virus infection. the selection of appropriate siRNA targets is a critical initial step in the development of antiviral RNAi therapeutics. successful siRNA designs must be based on the conserved sequences of the viral genome. no effective siRNAs targeting the conserved 5′ UTR of the EV71 genome have been reported. the application of unmodified 21 nt siRNAs and 2′-modified (2′-OMe and 2′-F) siRNAs to target highly conserved 5′ UTR of the EV71 genome for specific viral inhibition was investigated. nt double-stranded siRNAs containing 19-mer core sequences and 2d-TT at the 3′ ends were designed to target the 5′ UTR of the EV71 genome. the siRNA screening procedure was primarily based on a combination of RNA target accessibility prediction, siRNA duplex thermodynamic properties, and empirical design rules. the siRNA sequences are listed in Table 1. All siRNAs were synthesized by Genepharma Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China. the siRNA sequences are listed in the EV71 genome. EV71 suppresses toll-like receptor 3-mediated type I interferon responses by down-regulation of toll/interleukin-1 receptor domain-containing adaptor inducing beta interferon (TRIF) traditional interferon therapy showed only weak anti-EV71 activities and is not suitable for the treatment of EV71 infections in vitro. RNA nucleotide sequence analyses indicated that a mixture of the siRNAs targeting the 5′ UTR of the EV71 genome may have much broader antiviral effect on diverse EV71 strains. the most effective inhibition was observed for the siRNAs (si-2, si-2OMe, and si-1 F) targeting the 648–666 nt sequence of the 5′ UTR of the EV71 genome. target sequence located within the highly conserved 5′ UTR is a superiority with a reduced tendency to mutate. nucleotide sequence analyses suggest these siRNAs may have broader antiviral effects among EV71 China strains than the majority of previously reported siRNAs or shRNAs. both 2′-OMe and 2′-F modified siRNAs dramatically increased serum stability of the siRNAs in the present study. significant enhancements in serum stability of the siRNAs were observed in 10% FBS, 100% human serum, and 100% mouse serum compared with unmodified 21 nt siRNAs. cytotoxicity assays were used as a global indicator for monitoring adverse effects of unmodified and the 2′-modified 21 nt siRNAs. neither the unmodified nor the 2′-modified 21 nt siRNAs showed any significant cytotoxicity in contrast to the mock transfection control up to 72 h post-transfection. authors declare that they have no competing interests.
